properties.Name: A. O. Polymer

properties.Name: American Cyanamid Co.

properties.Name: Bog Creek Farm
properties.backgrou: This former Howell farm included a dumping ground for organic solvents and paint products that made their way into a pond, bog and trench on the property.  "To date, cleanup has included the removal of disposal pit wastes and disposal and incineration of

properties.Name: Brick Township Landfill
properties.backgrou: For 30 years, this landfill took in sewage, septic tank waste, solids and bulk liquids. In the 1970s, chemical wastes were also dumped on the site. By 2013, the site had been cleared and an impermeable cap was placed over the landfill, according to the E

properties.Name: Bridgeport Rental & Oil Services
properties.backgrou: This 30-acre property in Logan Township was home to a waste oil storage and recovery facility from 1960 into the early 80s. It included a "tank farm" and waste lagoon believed to have held 2.5 million gallons of oil tainted with PCBs, 80,000 cubic yards

properties.Name: Burnt Fly Bog
properties.backgrou: Once among the 10 worst Superfunds in the state, Burnt Fly Bog consists of a huge 1,700 acres at the edge of the pine barrens. Recycled waste oil operations and the presence of a former landfill tainted soil, sediment and surface water on the property. I

properties.Name: Caldwell Trucking Co.

properties.Name: Chemical Control

properties.Name: Chemsol, Inc.

properties.Name: Combe Fill South Landfill

properties.Name: CPS/Madison Industries
properties.backgrou: Comprised of two manufacturing facilities across 35 acres in Middlesex, this site saw decades of industrial activity in which the EPA says operators improperly handled and disposed of hazardous substances, including discharges into the public sewer syst

properties.Name: D'Imperio Property
properties.backgrou: The 15-acre site, located along the Black Horse Pike in Hamilton Township, is a former illegal dumping ground contaminated with volatile organic compounds. Its status is listed as "under control.

properties.Name: Dover Municipal Well 4
properties.backgrou: This town well was shut down in the 1980s after chlorinated volatile organic compounds were detected in the water. The source was traced to a dry cleaner, which was later demolished. The EPA says the site doesn't pose a threat as long as the well isn't u

properties.Name: Ellis Property

properties.Name: Evor Phillips Leasing

properties.Name: Fair Lawn Well Field

properties.Name: GEMS Landfill
properties.backgrou: This town-owned landfill in Gloucester Township operated from 1969 until it was shut down by the state in 1980. It was placed on the National Priorities List in 1983 and a major cleanup was done in 2004, according to the EPA, which says "long-term cleanu

properties.Name: Goose Farm
properties.backgrou: Located in Plumsted Township, this site was owned by a manufacturer of rocket fuel propellant and other industrial products that were dumped into a put dug into the sand, according to the EPA.  Soil cleanup has been completed. Long-term groundwater trea

properties.Name: Hercules, Inc. (Gibbstown Plant)

properties.Name: Imperial Oil Co., Inc./Champion Chemicals

properties.Name: JIS Landfill

properties.Name: Kin-Buc Landfill
properties.backgrou: Located across 220 sprawling acres in Edison, this site was once a state-approved landfill for industrial and municipal wastes, which began operating in the 1940s. One of the earliest entries onto the National Priorities List, the EPA claims that "all re

properties.Name: King of Prussia
properties.backgrou: According to the EPA, two companies treated industrial waste and disposed of hazardous liquids at this site in the early 1970s, treating approximately 15 million gallons of wastewater before it was abandoned in 1975. It was fenced off in the late 80s "to

properties.Name: Helen Kramer Landfill
properties.backgrou: This landfill shut down in 1981, but not before operations there contaminated groundwater with harmful chemicals. Following cleanup, long-term operation and maintenance activities for the site's remedy are ongoing," the EPA says.

properties.Name: Lang Property
properties.backgrou: This 40-acre site in Pemberton Township was for many years an illegal dumping ground littered with abandoned vehicles, tires and more than 1,200 drums of unidentified chemical waste. After property owners discovered the drums in the 1970s, they dumped th

properties.Name: Lipari Landfill
properties.backgrou: The Lipari Landfill was once ranked the most toxic dump in America  so polluted that federal officials gathered at the Pitman site in 1983 to announce the new federal program that came to be known as Superfund.  According to the EPA, from the 1950s into

properties.Name: Lone Pine Landfill
properties.backgrou: Another of New Jerseys most notorious sites, this 45-acre former landfill once contained at least 17,000 drums and several million gallons of bulk liquid chemical wastes of unknown origin, according to the EPA.  Three men, including two officials from

properties.Name: Maywood Chemical Co.
properties.backgrou: The Maywood Chemical Works processed radioactive thorium ore from 1916 to 1955. The work generated chemical and radioactive waste.  The site is being cleaned up by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the company deemed responsible for the contamination.

properties.Name: Metaltec/Aerosystems
properties.backgrou: This site saw the production of products including ballpoint pen parts, paint spraying equipment and lipstick cases, the byproducts of which seeped into soil and groundwater until it closed down in 1980.  "Sources of contamination at the site have been c

properties.Name: Montgomery Township Housing Development
properties.backgrou: The Montgomery Township Housing Development Superfund site was formerly home to industrial activities such as chemical manufacturing, resulting in soil and groundwater contamination by hazardous substances like volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and heavy metals. Recognized as a Superfund site in 1983, extensive cleanup efforts have included soil excavation to remove contaminated materials and installation of groundwater treatment systems to mitigate further spread of pollutants. While significant progress has been achieved, ongoing challenges persist in fully addressing the groundwater contamination and ensuring long-term environmental protection. Regular monitoring and remediation activities are vital to safeguarding public health and the environment in the area.

properties.Name: Myers Property
properties.backgrou: This site includes land owned by Arkema Inc. as well as two acres owned by the state of New Jersey, according to the EPA. It was once home to a pesticide production facility. The EPA is overseeing treatment and monitoring of groundwater.

properties.Name: NL Industries
properties.backgrou: This site was home to a lead smelting facility and was later used to recycle lead from spent car batteries. An on-site landfill was tainted with lead slag and other harmful contaminants.  "Access restrictions and cleanup activities to date have significa

properties.Name: PJP Landfill
properties.backgrou: The PJP Landfill was on fire for decades. Literally. In 1985, the Jersey Journal reported local and state authorities were trying in vain to tamp down the smoldering fires that had burned through the abandoned dump for years.  The site has since been cap

properties.Name: Price Landfill
properties.backgrou: This 26-acre area in Egg Harbor Township was a sand and gravel pit that became a landfill in the late 1960s, and saw more than nine million gallons of chemical waste dumped over more than a decade. The EPA says groundwater treatment and monitoring are "o

properties.Name: Rockaway Borough Well Field
properties.backgrou: The sister communities of Rockaway Township and Rockaway Borough each contain a separate Superfund site involving municipal wells. Both sites are roughly two square miles, with contamination tied to industrial activity in the town. The EPA lists both sit

properties.Name: Rockaway Township Wells
properties.backgrou: The Rockaway Township Wells Superfund site has a history tied to industrial activities, particularly metalworking and electroplating, which resulted in contamination of soil and groundwater with hazardous chemicals like trichloroethylene (TCE) and chromium. Designated a Superfund site in 1983, cleanup efforts have included soil excavation, installation of groundwater treatment systems, and containment measures. Despite progress, challenges remain in fully addressing the contamination and ensuring the safety of local water resources. Ongoing monitoring and remediation efforts are crucial to protecting public health and the environment in the area.

properties.Name: Rocky Hill Municipal Well
properties.backgrou: These two separate Superfund sites involve drinking water wells that were shut down in the late 1970s. According to the EPA, volatile organic compounds including trichloroethylene were detected in two wells at the Rocky Hill site in 1978. Concerned conta

properties.Name: Roebling Steel Co.
properties.backgrou: Located along the Delaware River in Florence Township, this sprawling 200-acre campus was the site of steel and wire manufacture and other industrial activities for decades. That legacy of industrial production left behind a litany of pollutants, from co

properties.Name: Scientific Chemical Processing
properties.backgrou: The Scientific Chemical Processing Superfund site in Harrison Township, Gloucester County, New Jersey, has been on the National Priorities List since 1990 due to hazardous waste contamination resulting from chemical processing activities conducted from the 1940s to the mid-1980s. Hazardous substances such as volatile organic compounds (VOCs), semi-volatile organic compounds (SVOCs), metals, and other chemicals have contaminated the soil and groundwater. Cleanup efforts overseen by the EPA have involved the removal of contaminated soil and the implementation of groundwater treatment systems. The EPA engages with the local community through public meetings and outreach activities to provide information about the site and involve stakeholders in the cleanup process. For the latest updates on the site's status and cleanup progress, individuals are advised to consult the EPA's website or contact the regional EPA office.

properties.Name: Sharkey Landfill
properties.backgrou: Located in the townships of Parsippany-Troy Hills and East Hanover, this 90-acre landfill accepted municipal wastes as well as commercial, industrial and hazardous waste materials, contaminating soil and groundwater with hazardous chemicals, according to

properties.Name: Swope Oil & Chemical Co.
properties.backgrou: This small Pennsauken site was once home to a chemical reclamation facility in the 60s and 70s. It processed solvents, oil, paints and other chemical compounds, which tainted the soil and groundwater.  "Site cleanup and monitoring are ongoing," the EPA s

properties.Name: Syncon Resins
properties.backgrou: This South Kearny facility made products used in pigments, paints and varnishes, and wastewater tinged with toxic xylene and toluene caused "extensive contamination of the groundwater, soil, buildings, vessels and tanks," according to EPA.  The sites g

properties.Name: Ciba-Geigy Corp.
properties.backgrou: These two Superfund sites in Toms River were the subject of the Pulitzer Prize-winning book "Toms River: A Story of Science and Salvation" by journalist Dan Fagin.  The former paint and pigment factory and the small farm that became an industrial dumping

properties.Name: Universal Oil Products (Chemical Division)
properties.backgrou: The Universal Oil Products (Chemical Division) Superfund site has been listed on the National Priorities List due to hazardous waste contamination stemming from activities conducted by the Universal Oil Products (UOP) Chemical Division. Throughout its operational history, which spanned several decades, the site was involved in chemical manufacturing processes that resulted in soil and groundwater contamination with volatile organic compounds (VOCs), heavy metals, and other hazardous substances. Cleanup efforts overseen by the EPA have entailed various remediation strategies, including soil excavation and treatment, groundwater monitoring, and the installation of containment systems. Community engagement initiatives led by the EPA aim to inform and involve local stakeholders in the cleanup process through public meetings and outreach activities. For the most recent updates on cleanup progress and site status, individuals are encouraged to refer to the EPA's website or contact the relevant EPA regional office.

properties.Name: U.S. Radium Corp.
properties.backgrou: The U.S. Radium Corp. operated a now-notorious factory in Orange that poisoned workers by using to the radioactive material to produce glow-in-the-dark watch faces and other products from 1917 to 1926.  The female workers at the plant and similar facilit

properties.Name: Williams Property
properties.backgrou: Located in Middle Township, this 5.6-acre tract saw about 150 drums of liquid chemical wastes and sludge dumped there in the late 70s, tainting soil and groundwater with hazardous chemicals. Groundwater treatment and monitoring are ongoing, according to

properties.Name: Woodland Route 72 Dump
properties.backgrou: Two dumps in Woodland Township located about two miles apart are listed separately on the federal Superfund list. The Route 72 site is an inactive industrial dump containing chemical contaminants, which was found by the EPA to be emitting gamma radiation

properties.Name: Chemical Leaman Tank Lines, Inc.

properties.Name: De Rewal Chemical Co.
properties.backgrou: This site was used by the DeRewal Chemical Company to store chemicals in the early 1970s. A series of spills,  including a tanker of chromium solution, contaminated soil and groundwater. The cleanup is listed as "ongoing."

properties.Name: Diamond Alkali Co.
properties.backgrou: One of New Jersey's most notorious Superfunds, the Passaic River and Newark Bay watershed has a long industrial legacy and a series of contaminated sites.  The Diamond Alkali Superfund site is a former Newark manufacturing facility where the Vietnam War-

properties.Name: Ewan Property
properties.backgrou: This 43-acre site in Shamong Township was a waste disposal property in the mid-1970s and was laden with a smorgasbord of pollutants including acetone, toluene, xylene, trichloroethylene, semi-volatile compounds and heavy metals such as arsenic, chromium

properties.Name: Landfill & Development Co.

properties.Name: Nascolite Corp.
properties.backgrou: Located in Millville and Vineland, this site was home to a facility that produced plexiglass from the 1950s into the 80s.  "Operators stored waste residues from the distillation of scrap acrylic in buried tanks on site," the EPA says. "Liquid wastes leak

properties.Name: Radiation Technology, Inc.
properties.backgrou: Located in Rockaway, this site saw a number of uses since the 1970s, including the rocket testing and development and radiation sterilization. The EPA claims the company "improperly stored and disposed of waste drums containing solvents and other organic

properties.Name: Shieldalloy Corp.
properties.backgrou: This Newfield location was once home to a specialty plant where chromium alloy and other materials were produced. Wastewater disposal led to groundwater contamination and the soil was contaminated with heavy metals, according to the EPA. "After initial a

properties.Name: Woodland Route 532 Dump
properties.backgrou: The Woodland Route 532 Dump Superfund site was added to the National Priorities List due to hazardous waste contamination resulting from historical dumping activities. Over time, the site became contaminated with various hazardous substances, including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), heavy metals, and other chemicals, posing risks to soil and groundwater. Cleanup efforts overseen by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have included remediation measures such as soil excavation, groundwater monitoring, and the implementation of containment systems to mitigate further spread of contaminants. The EPA engages with the local community to provide information about the site and involve stakeholders in the cleanup process through public meetings and outreach activities.

properties.Name: Vineland Chemical Co., Inc.
properties.backgrou: This area of mixed industrial and residential areas and farmland was once home to the Vineland Chemical Company, which produced arsenical herbicides and fungicides, contaminating the land and groundwater with arsenic.  "After immediate actions to protect

properties.Name: Ventron/Velsicol
properties.backgrou: The Ventron/Velsicol Superfund site was designated as a National Priorities List site due to extensive contamination resulting from historical chemical manufacturing activities conducted by Ventron Corporation and Velsicol Chemical Corporation. Hazardous substances, including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), pesticides, and heavy metals, have contaminated soil, groundwater, and surface water in the area. Cleanup efforts overseen by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have involved a range of remediation strategies, including soil excavation, groundwater treatment, and the implementation of containment measures to prevent further spread of contaminants. The EPA actively engages with the local community to provide information about the site and involve stakeholders in the cleanup process through public meetings and outreach initiatives.

properties.Name: Cinnaminson Township (Block 702) Ground Water Contamination

properties.Name: Fried Industries
properties.backgrou: The company produced floor finishing products, detergents and other products for a quarter century at this Milltown location, contaminating nearby wetlands. The EPA says it is now "under control."

properties.Name: Waldick Aerospace Devices, Inc.

properties.Name: Naval Weapons Station Earle (Site A)

properties.Name: Naval Air Engineering Center
properties.backgrou: An active Navy site in Lakehurst, the federal government has identified 44 potentially contaminated areas on the property.  "The areas included landfills, open pits, unlined lagoons and drainage ditches. Construction of the site's long-term remedies has

properties.Name: Monitor Devices, Inc./Intercircuits, Inc.

properties.Name: Dayco Corp./L.E. Carpenter Co.

properties.Name: Cosden Chemical Coatings Corp.

properties.Name: Curcio Scrap Metal, Inc.
properties.backgrou: This active scrap metal yard in Saddle Brook saw a spill of oil containing PCBs in the 1980s and a major cleanup project in the 90s. Because of the nature of the work done there, it was also contaminated with heavy metals and volatile organic compounds,

properties.Name: Brook Industrial Park
properties.backgrou: A small parcel of warehouses and industrial facility along the banks of the Raritan River, the EPA says this site was polluted by "various tenants" who had been cited "for poor housekeeping and waste disposal practices" that tainted soil and groundwater.

properties.Name: Pohatcong Valley Ground Water Contamination

properties.Name: Kauffman & Minteer, Inc.

properties.Name: Picatinny Arsenal (USARMY)

properties.Name: South Jersey Clothing Co.

properties.Name: Higgins Disposal
properties.backgrou: According to the EPA, a waste disposal company operated an unpermitted landfill, a waste transfer station and a compactor on this 38-acre property in Franklin Township from the 1950s into the 80s.  Around that time, area residents raised concerns to loca

properties.Name: Higgins Farm
properties.backgrou: This site includes two holding tanks filled with contaminated water and a barn contained with excavated drums of tainted soil on a cattle farm in Franklin Township.  "Following immediate actions to protect human health and the environment, EPA put the si

properties.Name: Global Sanitary Landfill
properties.backgrou: This former solid waste landfill was littered with buried drums containing paint, paint thinner and various solvents, according to the EPA.  "Groundwater underneath the site has been contaminated by pollutants leaching from the landfill," the EPA says

properties.Name: Garden State Cleaners Co.

properties.Name: Federal Aviation Administration Technical Center
properties.backgrou: Located eight miles north of Atlantic City, this site saw contamination from "FAA and National Guard activities" that tainted soil, sediment and groundwater in the area. The EPA oversaw "short-term" cleanups to contain threats to human health, but long-t

properties.Name: Chemical Insecticide Corp.
properties.backgrou: Another of New Jerseys most notorious Superfund sites, this small Edison site saw the production of bug and weed killers in the 1950s into the 70s.  Located in a residential neighborhood, it became a posterchild for orphan Superfunds when the Edison Wet

properties.Name: White Chemical Corp.
properties.backgrou: This Newark facility saw the production of acid chlorides and flame retardant compounds throughout the 1980s. The company was cited by the state DEP for violations and shut down in 1990. The EPA oversaw contaminated soil removal and is "nearing completio

properties.Name: Horseshoe Road
properties.backgrou: The Horseshoe Road Superfund site was added to the National Priorities List due to hazardous waste contamination stemming from various industrial activities conducted in the area. The site became contaminated with hazardous substances such as volatile organic compounds (VOCs) like benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene; heavy metals such as lead, mercury, and chromium; and other chemicals, posing risks to soil and groundwater. Cleanup efforts overseen by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have included remediation measures such as soil excavation, groundwater monitoring, and the implementation of containment systems to mitigate further spread of contaminants. The EPA engages with the local community to provide information about the site and involve stakeholders in the cleanup process through public meetings and outreach activities.

properties.Name: Franklin Burn
properties.backgrou: This Franklin Township site is actually made up of seven separate subsites where the EPA says copper wire was burned to remove insulation so the copper could be sold for scrap, leaving behind contaminated ash and debris piles.  Following response action

properties.Name: Welsbach & General Gas Mantle (Camden Radiation)

properties.Name: Cornell Dubilier Electronics, Inc.

properties.Name: LCP Chemicals Inc.

properties.Name: Puchack Well Field

properties.Name: Zschiegner Refining

properties.Name: Middlesex Sampling Plant (USDOE)
properties.backgrou: Opened in the 1940s, this site was part of the U.S.'s early nuclear energy infrastructure and was used to store and test nuclear materials including uranium, thorium, and beryllium.  It came under the control of the federal Department of Energy in 1980 a

properties.Name: United States Avenue Burn
properties.backgrou: The United States Avenue Burn Superfund site was designated as a National Priorities List site due to hazardous waste contamination resulting from an industrial fire that occurred in the area. The site became contaminated with hazardous substances such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), dioxins, furans, and heavy metals, including lead and mercury. These contaminants posed risks to soil, surface water, and nearby residential areas. Cleanup efforts overseen by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have involved remediation measures such as soil removal, sediment dredging, and the implementation of containment systems to prevent further spread of pollutants.

properties.Name: Emmell's Septic Landfill

properties.Name: Martin Aaron, Inc.

properties.Name: Iceland Coin Laundry Area Ground Water Plume

properties.Name: Lightman Drum Company
properties.backgrou: Located in Berlin, this 15-acre site used to be an industrial waste hauling and drum reclamation business. Drums containing hazardous chemicals were dumped in a pit on the site, contaminating soil and groundwater. The EPA says it oversaw short-term remed

properties.Name: McGuire Air Force Base #1
properties.backgrou: This active military facility is also a federal Superfund site. "Past activities at MAFB in support of operational missions created a number of waste sources of potential environmental concern," according to the EPA. "Site investigations and long-term cl

properties.Name: Diamond Head Oil Refinery Div.

properties.Name: Quanta Resources

properties.Name: Woodbrook Road Dump

properties.Name: Atlantic Resources Corporation

properties.Name: White Swan Cleaners/Sun Cleaners Area Ground Water Contamination

properties.Name: Standard Chlorine

properties.Name: Rolling Knolls Landfill

properties.Name: Sherwin-Williams/Hilliards Creek

properties.Name: Matteo & Sons, Inc.

properties.Name: Ringwood Mines/Landfill

properties.Name: Curtis Specialty Papers, Inc.
properties.backgrou: A former paper mill along the Delaware River in the Borough of Milford and Alexandria Township, the facility reported several spills on the property and received citations for unpermitted discharges and other infractions before it was shut down in 2003.

properties.Name: Raritan Bay Slag
properties.backgrou: The Laurence Harbor seawall was built up using lead slag in the late 1960s and 70s, contaminating the beach of the Raritan Bay in Old Bridge and Sayreville, according to the EPA. The agency approved a $79 million cleanup plan in 2013, but the company dee

properties.Name: Mansfield Trail Dump
properties.backgrou: In 2005, state and county health officials sampled drinking water wells in Byram Township and detected an industrial solvent, prompting them to install water filtration and treatment devices and systems to intercept chemical vapors seeping into the basem

properties.Name: Garfield Ground Water Contamination
properties.backgrou: The former E.C. Electroplating company's activity at this Garfield site spilled and leaked cancer-causing chromium into the ground, creating a plume of groundwater contamination at least a half a mile wide. One of New Jersey's orphan sites, the EPA hasn'

properties.Name: Orange Valley Regional Ground Water Contamination
properties.backgrou: The Orange Valley Regional Ground Water site, which includes two public-supply wells, provided drinking water to 10,000 people, according to the EPA. It was listed on the NPL in 2012 after testing found groundwater contaminated with common industrial che

properties.Name: Matlack, Inc.
properties.backgrou: Listed in 2013, this site includes a former truck, trailer and tanker-washing facility where contaminants and cleaning solutions were stored in an unlined lagoon, tainting soil and groundwater with volatile organic compounds and PCBs. Site investigation

properties.Name: Riverside Industrial Park
properties.backgrou: A seven-acre site used for a range of industries including paint manufacturing, a packaging company and a chemical warehouse since the early 20th century, the area was added to the Superfund list in 2013 after an oil spill into the Passaic River revealed

properties.Name: Pierson's Creek
properties.backgrou: Pierson's Creek is New Jersey's newest Superfund site after it was listed in 2014.  The creek, contaminated with mercury and other harmful pollutants, sits next to a plant operated by the Troy Chemical Corp. since the 1950s. According to the EPA, the com

properties.Name: Unimatic Manufacturing Corporation
properties.backgrou: Unimatic operated a metals molding facility at this Fairfield site from 1955 until 2001, discharging wastewater through leaky pipes that allowed PCBs to seep into the ground. The facility was so contaminated that state and federal health officials convin

properties.Name: Former Kil-Tone Company
properties.backgrou: The former Kil-Tone Company produced arsenic-based pesticides from the late 1910s into the late 1930s, leaving behind elevated concentrations of arsenic and lead. A new entry to the Superfund program, the site was listed in April 2016. The EPA says there

properties.Name: Pioneer Metal Finishing Inc
properties.backgrou: The Pioneer Metal Finishing Inc Superfund site was added to the National Priorities List due to hazardous waste contamination resulting from industrial operations conducted at the facility. Hazardous substances such as trichloroethylene (TCE), dichloroethylene (DCE), and other volatile organic compounds (VOCs) contaminated soil and groundwater, posing risks to the surrounding environment and potentially impacting nearby residential areas. Cleanup efforts overseen by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have included remediation measures such as soil excavation, groundwater treatment, and the implementation of containment systems to prevent further spread of contaminants.

properties.Name: Lower Hackensack River
properties.backgrou: The Lower Hackensack River Superfund site was designated as a National Priorities List site due to extensive contamination in the Lower Hackensack River and surrounding areas. Industrial activities and urban runoff have contributed to the presence of hazardous substances such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), heavy metals including mercury, lead, and cadmium, as well as various volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in sediment and surface water, posing risks to aquatic life and public health. Cleanup efforts overseen by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have included dredging contaminated sediment, capping, and habitat restoration to reduce exposure and restore ecological balance.
